reviewText:
Based on the description alone, one can tell that this documentary shows Alinsky as a man of the people, helping the people to come to power. The description shows nothing but admiration or Alinsky, as if all he was about was helping "the people!" get the country they deserve.

For 99 cents you can see what Alinsky was really about, or at least consider that he may have been about more than this documentary acknowledges or is even aware of.

Another reviewer said that Alinsky was taught in college. I don't doubt it.

Do you guys have any idea what students were taught in Germany before WWI and then before WWII? Do you have any idea what students were taught during the rise of Mussolini?

To see the common philosophies guiding communists, socialists, national socialists, fascists, and progressives, including Wilson, FDR, JFK and Johnson and Obama and modern progressives, very much including Alinsky and Soros, read this:

http://www.amazon.com/Breaking-System-Obamas-Strategy-Change-ebook/dp/B0058OCK1A/ref=pd_sim_kstore_15?ie=UTF8&refRID=03HE1CY1GNJFEBG63T1D

or this:

http://www.amazon.com/Barack-Obamas-Rules-Revolution-Alinsky-ebook/dp/B009KSFK8U/ref=pd_sim_kstore_3?ie=UTF8&refRID=08PHRVEGR5RNZB58B1K0

and this would be good:

http://www.amazon.com/Liberal-Fascism-American-Mussolini-Politics-ebook/dp/B000W917ZG/ref=sr_1_1?s=digital-text&ie=UTF8&qid=1411887823&sr=1-1&keywords=liberal+fascism

Got this for my grad school students studying activists. A wonderful depiction of Alinsky's life and philosophy. Has real footage of Saul and some of his social action work. Students really liked it, too.
A well made film about a very important man, Saul Alinsky, who helped many people to change their own lives for the better.
This movie is great for anyone looking for insight into the politics and organizational theory of the father of modern day community organizing.

A thinly veiled attempt a distorting the true socialist agenda of this Chicago organizer, who provided the roadmap for Obama's handlers.  These people want to destroy America and the ideals upon which she was founded.
They are about statist power grabs and oppression of the very people they claim to want to help.

Robert Putnam has traced for us the symptoms of the decline of our democracy as we fail to vote, fail to register to vote, fail to know the names of our neighbors, fail to join clubs like Kiwanis or Rotary, fail to connect with those nearest us.  Saul Alinsky proposed an alternative years ago in community organizing.  As goes the strength of our local communities, so goes the nation.  This film recounts the efforts of Alinsky and his proteges in community organizing.

Alinsky made a difference, and, perhaps, we too might make a difference in our world today.

This documentary is a good introduction to the work of legendary organizer, Saul Alinsky. Narrated by Alec Baldwin, and featuring interviews with many people Alinsky worked with, "The Democratic Promise" shows how people learned to get together and lobby their government and workplaces to promote their welfare. Starting in meat-packing plants, moving on to struggles for housing, and being picked up by Vietnam war protestors, Alinsky's guidance has helped countless people to pressure for their causes. The story of a community group working for housing in East Brooklyn is one of many inspiring stories in the film. There's a wonderful scene when Mayor Rudolph Giulianni comes to their church and announces that he will support their cause and that they will receive the funding they need for their project. Alinsky's Rules for Radicals continues to be widely read by organizers. Hillary Clinton's Wikipedia biography mentions that she did a paper on Alinsky, and Saul's ideas also influenced activists like Cesar Chavez and Stokely Carmichael. Alinsky also pioneered "shareholder activism" The Emperor's Nightingale: Restoring the Integrity of the Corporation in the Age of Shareholder Activism Making Waves and Riding the Currents: Activism and the Practice of Wisdom (BK Currents). Alinsky's life was a testament to what Frederick Douglass said about how power concedes nothing without a struggle. This film is a much needed reminder of the need for that struggle, and the power that people do have when they organize. See also This Is What Democracy Looks Like and What Would Jefferson Do?: A Return to Democracy by radio host Thom Hartmann. And for an international perspective on organizing Cocalero.
